newsitem.title: USA: Jury deadlocks on militia conspiracy charges.
newsitem.headline: Jury deadlocks on militia conspiracy charges.

text.p: A federal jury on Friday convicted several anti-government militia members of possessing pipe bombs and machine guns but were unable to agree on whether they engaged in a conspiracy to kill federal agents.

After a five-week trial and eight days of jury deliberation, U.S. District Judge John Coughenour declared a mistrial on the most serious conspiracy counts against the seven defendants, members of the anti-government Freemen and Washington State Militia.
He ordered federal prosecutors to decide quickly whether to retry the defendants, including John Pitner, self-declared director of the state militia.
Pitner, 45, and the six other defendants were arrested July 27 in Seattle and Bellingham, where agents found pipe bombs and other explosive devices allegedly made by members of the group.
Federal agents arrested five members of the group at a bomb-making class after a seven-month undercover investigation.
Defence attorneys argued that the defendants were coerced into making the explosives by the undercover agents, and they said their clients were tried for their unpopular beliefs.
"Our position was these people talked a lot, but there was no conspiracy to kill or impede the federal government," said Robert Leen, attorney for one of the defendants.

According to trial testimony, two of the self-described Freemen had approached the militia members for training with the objective of travelling to Jordan, Montana, during the FBI siege of a foreclosed ranch.
The Freemen received limited training, include practice shooting at targets representing federal agents and U.S. Attorney General Janet Reno.
But when the 81-day standoff ended peacefully, the project was dropped.
Coughenour ordered two defendants -- who faced only conspiracy charges -- to be released after jurors said they were hopelessly deadlocked.
Pitner was found guilty of possessing a machine gun, as was Gary Kuehnoel, 47, Marlin Mack, 24, and John Kirk, 56, were found guilty of possessing pipe bombs or other destructive devices.
An eighth defendant pleaded guilty previously.
A spokeswoman for federal prosecutors said a decision on whether to seek a retrial would be made within two weeks.
